bondTypes.name: Ball Bonding
bondTypes.description: The Speed King - Used for >90% of ICs (CPUs, Memory, Microcontrollers). It is omni-directional (can loop in any direction).

processSteps.name: EFO (Electronic Flame Off)
processSteps.description: A high-voltage spark melts the wire tip inside a ceramic Capillary, forming a Free Air Ball (FAB).

processSteps.name: First Bond (Ball Bond)
processSteps.description: Capillary descends to the die pad. Heat + Ultrasonic Scrub welds the ball to the pad.

processSteps.name: Looping
processSteps.description: Capillary rises to 'Kink Height,' moves in 'Reverse Motion' to bend the wire, then moves to the second pad.

processSteps.name: Second Bond (Stitch Bond)
processSteps.description: Capillary crushes the wire against the leadframe using the 'outer radius' of the capillary tip. This is a Wedge-shaped bond.

processSteps.name: Tail Break
processSteps.description: The wire clamps close, and the capillary rises, tearing the wire at the 'Heel' of the stitch.

disadvantages: Ball takes up space (limits minimum pitch)

bondTypes.name: Wedge Bonding
bondTypes.description: The Fine Pitch Specialist - Used for Aluminum wire and Ribbon. It is uni-directional (the tool must rotate to face the wire direction).

processSteps.name: Wire Feed
processSteps.description: The wire is fed under a wedge tool. No ball is formed.

processSteps.name: First Bond
processSteps.description: The tool crushes the side of the wire onto the pad using Ultrasonic energy.

processSteps.name: Loop
processSteps.description: Tool moves to the second pad.

processSteps.name: Second Bond
processSteps.description: Another wedge crush completes the bond.

advantages: Can achieve finer pitch (pad spacing) than ball bonding
No large ball to take up space
Works well with aluminum wire and ribbon
disadvantages: Uni-directional (tool must rotate to face wire direction)
Slower than ball bonding due to rotation requirement

bondTypes.name: Security Bonds / Safety Bumps
bondTypes.description: A reinforcement technique where a ball bond is placed on top of the stitch bond after the loop is finished to anchor the stitch down.

processSteps.name: Complete Standard Loop
processSteps.description: Perform standard ball bonding process with first bond, loop, and stitch bond.

processSteps.name: Security Bond Placement
processSteps.description: Place a ball bond on top of the stitch bond to anchor it down.

parameters.problem: Stitch Bond (2nd bond) is the weakest link - often lifts off

bondTypes.name: Standoff Stitch (SOS) / Ball Stitch on Ball (BSOB)
bondTypes.description: Reverse Bonding technique critical for low-profile packages. Standard forward bonding has a high loop arc; reverse bonding allows the loop to be extremely flat.

processSteps.name: Bump Placement
processSteps.description: Place a gold Bump on the die pad.

processSteps.name: Reverse Loop
processSteps.description: Create a loop from the leadframe back to the die.

processSteps.name: Stitch on Bump
processSteps.description: Stitch the wire onto the top of the gold Bump.

advantages: Bump protects die from heavy force of stitch bond
